sen.j: 伏見稲荷大社（ふしみいなりたいしゃ）は京都市伏見区にある神社である。
sen.e: Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi-ku Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 稲荷神を祀る全国約4万社の稲荷神の総本宮である。
sen.e: It is the head shrine of the approximately 40,000 shrines around the country that enshrine the god Inari.
It is the head shrine of the approximately 40,000 shrines around the country that enshrine the god Inari.
It is the head shrine of the approximately 40,000 shrines around the country that enshrine the Inari-shin (the god of harvest).

sen.j: 稲荷山の麓に本殿があり、稲荷山全体を神域とする。
sen.e: The main hall is situated at the foot of Mt. Inarisan and shrine precinct is considered to consist of the entire mountain.
The main hall is situated at the foot of Mt. Inarisan and the shrine precinct is considered to consist of the entire mountain.
The main hall is situated at the foot of Mt. Inari and the shrine precinct is considered to consist of the entire mountain.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大）、二十二社の上七社の一社で、旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: The shrine is listed (categorized as a Myojin Taisha) in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki, one of the upper seven of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and was classified as a Kanpei Taisha under the former shrine ranking system

The shrine is listed (categorized as a Myojin Taisha) in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki, one of the upper seven of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and was classified as a Kanpei Taisha under the former shrine ranking system

The shrine is Shikinai-sha (Myojin Taisha) (shrine listed in Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) laws), one of the upper seven of the Twenty-Two Shrines, and was classified as a Kanpei Taisha (the first rank of government supported shrines) under the former shrine ranking system
sen.cmt: 「式内社（名神大）」「官幣大社」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: ウカノミタマ（うかのみたまのおおかみ）を主祭神とし、佐田彦大神、大宮能売大神、田中大神、四大神を配祀する。
sen.e: The main enshrined deity is Ukano Mitamano Ookami, which is enshrined along with Satahikono Ookami, Oomiyanomeno Ookami, Tanakano Ookami and Shino Ookami.
The main enshrined deity is Ukano Mitamano Ookami, which is enshrined along with Satahikono Ookami, Oomiyanomeno Ookami, Tanakano Ookami and Shino Ookami.
The main enshrined deity is Ukano Mitamano Okami, which is enshrined along with Satahikono Okami, Omiyanomeno Okami, Tanakano Okami and Shino Okami.
sen.cmt: 長音表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 稲荷神が農業の神であるために、五穀豊穰・商売繁盛・交通安全といったご利益がある。
sen.e: As the god of agriculture, Inari is believed to grant abundant harvests, prosperous business and traffic safety.
As the god of agriculture, Inari is believed to grant abundant harvests, prosperous business and traffic safety.
As the god of agriculture, Inari is believed to grant abundant harvests, prosperous business and traffic safety.

sen.j: 2008年の初詣（正月三が日）の参拝者数は約269万人で、関西の社寺では最も多かった。
sen.e: In 2008, the shrine received approximately 2,690,000 visitors for Hatsumode (the first prayer of the New Year) - the most of any temple or shrine in the Kansai region.
In 2008, the shrine received approximately 2,690,000 visitors for Hatsumode (the first prayer of the New Year) - the most of any temple or shrine in the Kansai region.

In 2008, approximately 2,690,000 people visited it for Hatsumode (New Year's visit to a shrine or a temple) during the first three days of the New Year - the most of any temple or shrine in the Kansai region.

sen.j: （警察庁発表による）
sen.e: This figure was released by the National Police Agency.
This figure was released by the National Police Agency.
This figure was released by the National Police Agency.

sen.j: 711年（和銅4年）2月壬午の日に、伊侶具秦公（はたのきみのいろく）が勅命を受けて伊奈利山三ヶ峯（稲荷山）に三柱の神を祀ったことに始まる。
sen.e: The origin of Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine lies in the Imperial order received by HATANOKIMI no Iroku on the day of Mizunoe-uma in the second month of the year 711 which commanded him to enshrine three gods at Inariyama Mitsugamine (Inariyama).

The origin of Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine lies in the Imperial order received by HATANOKIMI no Iroku on the day of Mizunoe-uma in the second month of the year 711 which commanded him to enshrine three gods at Inariyama Mitsugamine (Inariyama).

The origin of Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine lies in the Imperial order received by HATANOKIMI no Iroku on the day of Mizunoe-uma in March 4, 711, which commanded him to enshrine mihashirano kami (three gods) at Mitsugamine peak of Mt. Inari.
sen.cmt: 「711年（和銅4年）2月壬午の日」を西暦に直し、「三柱の神」の訳を統一しました。

sen.j: 山城国風土記逸文には伊侶具秦公が稲荷神を祀ることになった経緯が書かれている。
sen.e: The lost Yamashiro Province gazetteer described the course of events that led to HATANOKIMI no Iroku enshrining Inari.
The lost Yamashiro Province gazetteer described the course of events that led to HATANOKIMI no Iroku enshrining Inari.

Yamashiro no kuni Fudoki Itsubun (a description of the natural features, culture and history of Yamashiro Province, which is unknown or lost) described how and why HATANOKIMI no Iroku enshrined Inari.

sen.j: 秦氏にゆかり深い神社である。
sen.e: The shrine has a deep connection to the Hata clan.
The shrine has a deep connection to the Hata clan.
The shrine has a deep connection to the Hata clan.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には「稲荷神社三座」と記載され、名神大社に列し、月次・新甞の幣帛を受けると書かれている。
sen.e: The Register of Deities of the Engishiki lists the shrine as 'Inari Jinja Sanza', classifies it as a Myojin Taisha, and describes that paper or silk offerings are left each month and during the harvest festival.

The Register of Deities of the Engishiki lists the shrine as 'Inari Jinja Sanza', classifies it as a Myojin Taisha, and describes that paper or silk offerings are left each month and during the harvest festival.

In Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine is described as 'Inari Jinja Sanza' (Inari-jinja shrine of three thrones), classified as a Myojin Taisha (shrines that enshrine gods known as Myojin), and recieved heihaku (a sacramental strip of silk (offered to the gods)) every month and at the harvest festival.
sen.cmt: 「稲荷神社三座」の訳などを補足しました。[http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=783]

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）には近代社格制度のもとで官幣大社に列格するとともに、正式社名を「稲荷神社」とし、「官幣大社稲荷神社」となったが、戦後の1946年に神社本庁とは独立した単立宗教法人となり、「伏見稲荷大社」と改称した。
sen.e: As well as being classified as a Kanpei Taisha (Imperial shrine) under the modern shrine ranking system in 1871, it's formal name was changed to 'Inari-jinja' to become 'Kanpei Taisha Inari-jinja', but in 1946 after the Second World War it became a religious corporation independent from the Association of Shinto Shrines and its name was changed to 'Fushimi Inari Taisha'.

As well as being classified as a Kanpei Taisha (Imperial shrine) under the modern shrine ranking system in 1871, it's formal name was changed to 'Inari-jinja' to become 'Kanpei Taisha Inari-jinja', but in 1946 after the Second World War it became a religious corporation independent from the Association of Shinto Shrines and its name was changed to 'Fushimi Inari Taisha'.

With classified as a Kanpei Taisha (Imperial shrine) under the modern shrine ranking system in 1871, the shrine changed its formal name to 'Inari-jinja' to become 'Kanpei Taisha Inari-jinja', but in 1946, after the Second World War, it became a stand-alone religious corporation independent from the Association of Shinto Shrines and its name was changed to 'Fushimi Inari Taisha'.
sen.cmt: 表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: これは、神社本庁が伊勢神宮を本宗とするとしているが、伏見稲荷としてはそれを受け入れるわけにいかないという理由である。
sen.e: This split was due to the fact that the Association of Shinto Shrines considers Ise-jingu Shrine to be the head of all shrines, but this was unacceptable for Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine.
This split was due to the fact that the Association of Shinto Shrines considers Ise-jingu Shrine to be the head of all shrines, but this was unacceptable for Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine.
This split was due to the fact that the Association of Shinto Shrines considers Ise-jingu Shrine to be the head of all shrines, but this was unacceptable for Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine.

sen.j: 神社本庁とは「喧嘩別れ」したわけではなく、関係は良好である。
sen.e: Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine's separation from the Association of Shinto Shrines was not a falling out and two parties enjoy a good relationship.
Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine's separation from the Association of Shinto Shrines was not a falling out and the two parties enjoy a good relationship.
Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine's separation from the Association of Shinto Shrines was not a falling out and the two parties enjoy a good relationship.

sen.j: 社家には学者が多く、国学者の荷田春満も当社の社家出身である。
sen.e: The family of hereditary priests who serve the shrine has produced many scholars and includes the ancient Japanese literature and culture scholar KADA no Azumamaro.
The family of hereditary priests who serve the shrine has produced many scholars and includes the ancient Japanese literature and culture scholar KADA no Azumamaro.
The family of hereditary priests who serve the shrine has produced many scholars and includes KADA no Azumamaro, the scholar of ancient Japanese literature and culture.
sen.cmt: 表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 境内には荷田春満の旧宅が保存されており、隣設して荷田春満を祭神とする東丸神社がある（元は摂末社であったが、現在は独立した神社）。
sen.e: The former residence of KADA no Azumamaro has been preserved within the shrine precinct and stands adjacent to the Azumamaro-jinja Shrine which enshrines his kami (was originally a branch shrine but is now independent).

The former residence of KADA no Azumamaro has been preserved within the shrine precinct and stands adjacent to the Azumamaro-jinja Shrine which enshrines his kami (was originally a branch shrine but is now independent).

The former residence of KADA no Azumamaro has been preserved within the shrine precinct and stands adjacent to the Azumamaro-jinja Shrine which enshrines him as a deity (originally Setsumatsu sha (smaller shrine managed under the shrine) but is now independent).
sen.cmt: 「摂末社」などの表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 現在の本殿は、応仁の乱で焼失した後に明応8年（1499年）に再建されたもので、国の重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The current main building was rebuilt in 1499 following the destruction of the previous structure during the Onin War and has been designated an Important Cultural Property.
The current main building was rebuilt in 1499 following the destruction of the previous structure during the Onin War and has been designated an Important Cultural Property.
The current main building was rebuilt in 1499 after the previous structure was destroyed by fire during the Onin War and has been designated an Important Cultural Property.
sen.cmt: 表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 稲荷山には信者から奉納された約一万基の鳥居があり、特に千本鳥居は名所となっている。
sen.e: Approximately 10,000 torii dedicated by devotees stand on Mt. Inarisan, among which the senbon torii (thousand torii) are particularly famous.
Approximately 10,000 torii dedicated by devotees stand on Mt. Inarisan, among which the senbon torii (thousand torii) are particularly famous.
Approximately 10,000 torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine) dedicated by devotees stand on Mt. Inari, among which the Senbon Torii (a thousand torii) are particularly famous.
sen.cmt: 「鳥居」の英訳を補足し、表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 鳥居を奉納する習わしは江戸時代に始まった。
sen.e: The custom to dedicate torii started during the Edo period.

sen.j: 無数の石碑（その数、一万基、あるいはそれ以上とも言われる）が存在し、「お塚」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: The countless stone monuments (said to number at least 10,000) are known as 'Otsuka'.
The countless stone monuments (said to number at least 10,000) are known as 'Otsuka'.
In the precinct, there are the countless stone monuments (said to number at least 10,000) known as 'Otsuka.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置などを変えました。

sen.j: 各石碑には「白狐大神」や「白龍大神」などといった神名が記されている。
sen.e: These have all been engraved with the names of gods such as 'Byakko Ookami' and 'Hakuryu Ookami'.
These have all been engraved with the names of gods such as 'Byakko Ookami' and 'Hakuryu Ookami'.
These have all been engraved with the names of gods such as 'Byakko Okami' (deity of albino fox) and 'Hakuryu Okami' (deity of white dragon).
sen.cmt: 音引き表現を合わせ、英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 参拝者の中には、石碑の前にひざまづいて「般若心経」などを唱えている人もおり、日本で神仏分離が行われる前の信仰（→神仏習合）が今でも保たれているのを見ることができる。
sen.e: Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine retains the beliefs that existed before the separation of Shintoism and Buddhism (syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism), and there are even visitors who kneel in front of these stone monuments and recite the Heart Sutra.

Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine retains the beliefs that existed before the separation of Shintoism and Buddhism (syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism), and there are even visitors who kneel in front of these stone monuments and recite the Heart Sutra.

Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine retains the beliefs that existed before the separation of Shintoism and Buddhism (syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism), and there are even visitors who kneel in front of these stone monuments and recite Hannya Shingyo (Heart Sutra).
sen.cmt: 表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道奈良線：稲荷駅（京都駅から普通列車に乗り換え。
sen.e: West Japan Railway Company, Nara-Line: Inari Station (transfer to a local train from Kyoto Station).
West Japan Railway Company, Nara-Line: Inari Station (transfer to a local train from Kyoto Station).
West Japan Railway Company, Nara-Line: Inari Station (transfer to a local train from Kyoto Station).

sen.j: 所要時間は約5分。
sen.e: The journey takes approximately 5 minutes.
The journey takes approximately 5 minutes.
The journey takes approximately 5 minutes.

sen.j: 正月を除いて快速列車は停車しない）
sen.e: Express trains only stop at this station during the New Year holiday.
Express trains only stop at this station during the New Year holiday.
Express trains only stop at this station during the New Year holiday.

sen.j: 京阪電気鉄道京阪本線：伏見稲荷駅
sen.e: Keihan Electric Railway, Keihan-Honsen (main line): Fushimi Inari Station.
Keihan Electric Railway, Keihan-Honsen (main line): Fushimi Inari Station.
Keihan Electric Railway, Keihan-Honsen (main line): Fushimi Inari Station.
